R. China, 400044. Graphical abstract Potential energy for methane successive dehydrogenation on Ni(111) and NiPt(111) surfaces. Methane dehydrogenation is a well-studied reaction that is of both scientific and industrial importance. We performed systematic density functional theory computations to examine the catalytic performance of pure and Pt modified Ni(111) surfaces for carbon formation from methane dehydrogenation. To address these processes, Ni-Pt surface alloys of 6 different bimetallic compositions are applied to investigate the detailed catalytic dehydrogenation for methane, and their catalytic activities as well as resistance to carbon formation are compared with monometallic Ni(111) surface. Through the systematic examination, the results show that CH4 dissociation into CH3 +H and CH decomposition into C+H are the two key steps. Moreover, it is found that CH dissociation barriers on the Ni-Pt bimetallic surfaces are evidently higher that on pure Ni(111). Especially for NiPt(111)-B1 surface, energy barrier for CH dissociation is remarkably increased by around 1.7eV compared to that on Ni(111) and the carbon adsorption energy is the lowest one among all surfaces. The enhanced barrier suppresses the CH cracking reaction and reduced carbon adsorption energy diminishes the possibility of coke formation. Additionally, carbon formation is significantly inhibited even with a small amount of Pt addition. Considering the balance between the catalytic performance and the economic cost, we proposed that NiPt(111)-B1 surface not only exhibits good resistance to carbon formation, but also has the moderate cost due to the less doped Pt atoms, although there is a slight decrease in activation for methane. Finally, BEP relationships between reaction energy and activation energy have been developed for every methane dehydrogenation step on all Ni(111) and NiPt(111) surfaces in this paper. These results could provide new mechanistic insight into the role of Pt in improving the ability to anti carbon formation of Ni catalysts, and are helpful to understand the mechanisms of methane dissociation from the atomic scale. Keywords Methane dehydrogenation Ni(111) NiPt(111) DFT Carbon formation 1 Introduction Due to the massive available in natural gas and shale gas reserves, the catalytic activation and conversion of methane is of great interest both in the catalytic community and chemical industry [1–4]. This reaction is involved in some important chemical processes, such as methane total oxidation [3,5], methane partial oxidation [6,7], methane steam reforming [8,9] and methane dry reforming [10,11]. Above all, methane dissociation is the key step for all these chimerical processes. In addition, the Ni-based catalysts are considered as an attractive candidate for this reaction in present and future industry application due to their low cost and high activity [12,13]. However, carbon deposition is a serve problem for Ni catalysts, which would lead to rapid deactivation [14]. The deactivation of catalyst due to the coke formation [15] has become to a major obstacle to the commercialization of methane conversion over the catalysts, especially for Ni. Therefore, reduction and elimination of the carbon deposits and improving the catalysts stability and activity are of great importance and are the subjects of enormous experimental and theoretical researches. Generally speaking, one approach is to modify the Ni catalyst by itself, such as adding noble metals. Another approach is to modify the environment of the heterogeneous reactions, such as applying an external electric field [16–18]. Our present work focuses on improving the Ni catalyst performance by adding noble metals. Noble metals have been studied and typically found to be much more resistant to carbon deposition than Ni catalysts [10,19,20], but are generally uneconomical. Noble metals like Pt, Rh and Ru are highly active towards methane dissociation and more resistant to carbon formation than other transition metals [21–23]. Therefore, noble metals can also be used to promote the Ni catalysts to increase their resistance to deactivation and the stability. Many studies have proven that bimetallic Ni-based catalysts with special electronic effect and surface structure, exhibit good catalytic activity and strong carbon deposition resistance for methane dissociation [22,24,25], methane dry reforming (DRM) [26–28] and methane steam reforming (SRM) [29,30]. Several factors have been suggested to rationalize the synergistic effect over bimetallic surfaces [22,31,32]: (a) ensemble effect that refers to the variation in the catalytic property of an ensemble when its chemical composition changes; (b) ligand effect that arises from the interaction between adjacent metal atoms of different elements; (c) strain effect that is related to the modification of surface electronic structure through the variation in orbital overlapping. Experimental approaches have been exploited to gain deeper insight into the effect of the noble metals doped on the reaction activity, stability and coke resistance of Ni catalysts. It has been reported that a certain amount of noble metals addition could promote the reducibility of the base metals, such as Ni, and lower or even eliminate the carbon deposits in the methane catalytic conversion processes [26–30]. Activity tests demonstrated that Pt presence in Ni catalyst inhibits coke deposition, reduces operation temperature and enhances the stability of Ni-based catalysts for DRM [26]. It has also been confirmed the formation of Pt-Ni alloy has smaller metal crystal size than metal particles in monometallic Pt and Ni catalysts, which shows a good performance for coke resistance [27]. Additionally, nanostructured Pt-Ni catalysts supported on alumina were studied for DRM [28]. It was observed that there is a Pt–Ni interaction between metallic centers, which enhances the catalyst stability and selectivity towards H2 and CO. Li et al. [29] studied the surface modification of Ni catalysts with trace Pt for oxidative steam reforming of methane. The results suggested that Pt-Ni species is active for both reforming and combustion reactions, which leads to a lower bed temperature and smaller temperature gradient than those seen for the monometallic Ni catalysts. Supported Ni and Ni/Rh catalysts were synthesized and tested for liquid hydrocarbon steam reforming [30]. Carbon analysis on the spent catalysts illustrated that the carbon deposition is significantly suppressed with inclusion of Rh. On the other hand, as a fast developing approach recently, quantum chemical calculation may shed some light on a better understanding of this catalytic process on a micro level. In the last two decades, density functional theory (DFT) has become a powerful tool to explore elementary steps and mechanisms of many heterogeneously catalyzed processes at the atomic scale [33]. Furthermore, DFT calculations can also be used to validate the experimental observations or to give explanations in depth [34]. Therefore, the fundamental understanding offered by DFT calculations still serve as a cornerstone in the complete process of computer-aided catalytic design. Through the first-principles study, Huang et al. [35] have found that the Au/Ni surface alloys are suggested to be less active to methane dissociation, but more resistant to carbon formation even with a small amount of Au addition. Bothra and Pati [36] revealed that the deposition of carbon is largely suppressed by the addition of a Rh overlayer on the pure Ni(110) surface. In addition, theoretical study on the dissociative adsorption of CH4 on Pd-doped Ni surfaces indicated that Pd-doping raises the activation barrier for CH dissociation, which helps to reduce carbon deposition [37]. A DFT theoretical study of CH4 dissociation on gold-alloyed Ni(111) surface demonstrated that the reaction barriers are higher in the first and the fourth steps on gold-alloyed Ni(111) compared with those on pure Ni(111) [38]. DFT calculations were performed to study the effect of Ni(111) surface alloying by Pt on partial oxidation of methane to syngas [39]. The results showed that Pt-doped Ni(111) surface is beneficial to the adsorption of CHx and H species and the process of CH→C+H is found to be RDS (Rate Determining Step) in methane dissociation on NiPt(111). Fan et al. [22] investigated the origin of synergistic effect over Ni-based bimetallic surfaces (NiM; M=Cu, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ag, Pt and Au) for methane dissociation. The results demonstrated that Pt-promoted Ni catalyst shows the best coke resistance. As mentioned above, Pt-Ni bimetallic catalysts show the good performance for carbon resistance, activity and stability from both the experimental and theoretical studies in methane activation. Moreover, Pt-Ni bimetallic species have been gain great interests in research of material and catalytic science [40–43]. However, there is limited literature on methane dissociation over Pt-Ni catalysts of different bimetallic compositions studied by DFT systematically at the atomic scale. In addition, the NiPt(111) surface was simply constructed by substituting the middle Ni atom with one Pt atom on the topmost layer of Ni(111) surface [39] or the Ni2M and N3 sites [22] have been taken into account in previous computational work. However, one pure Ni(111) surface and other 6 Pt-Ni surface alloys of different bimetallic compositions have been constructed and applied in our present study, which will be shown in details in Section 2 of this paper. In order to design Ni-based catalysts that minimize the deactivation and improve the carbon resistance by doping Pt, understanding the elementary steps in CH4 dehydrogenation is absolutely indispensable. In our present work, the adsorption energies of the reactants, intermediates and products, and the activation barriers as well as reaction heat for the elementary reactions in methane dehydrogenation are calculated over the Ni(111) and NiPt(111) surfaces, respectively. Reaction paths over different surfaces have been analyzed and compared. Moreover, the role of Pt addition in resistance to carbon formation has been explained and elucidated. It could provide some useful information for the operation of methane activation and conversion over monometallic Ni and bimetallic Ni-Pt catalysts, and is helpful to understand the mechanisms of methane dissociation from the atomic scale. 2 Computational details 2.1 Computational models Metal (111) surface is regarded as the major exposed surface in face center cubic (fcc) and hexagonal close-packed (hcp) structures [39]. In addition, the (111) surface usually dominates the surfaces of metal nanoparticles [44], so pure Ni(111) and bimetallic NiPt(111) are chosen as the reaction surface in this paper. Based on the optimized pure Ni bulk and Pt-doped Ni bulk, the four atomic layers Ni(111) and NiPt(111) surface models were built. The bottom two layers were fixed, and the top two layers and the adsorbates were allowed to relax. Additionally, a p(2×2) supercell was applied, with a coverage of adsorbates of 1/4 ML, which has been widely used in previous DFT study dealing with molecular interactions with metal surfaces at a relative low computational cost for methane dissociation [22–25]. Furthermore, the p(3×3) supercell was calculated to obtain the necessary surface size effect suggesting that a p(2×2) supercell is sufficient in size to neglect the surrounding adsorbate interactions. Thus, a p(2×2) supercell was employed in our present work. The computational method results in a self-consistent lattice constant of 3.55Å for the Ni bulk, which is in good agreement with the well accepted experimental value 3.52Å [45]. Six different bimetallic NiPt bulks were built based on an optimized pure Ni bulk by substituting Ni with Pt atoms. The pure Ni bulk & Pt doped Ni bulks and the corresponding metal (111) surfaces are provided in Table 1 . In addition, the electron density for all Ni(111) and NiPt(111) surfaces are given in Table S1 in Supplementary material. 2.2 Density functional theory (DFT) calculations Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed with the program Cambridge Sequential Total Energy Package 8.0 (CASTEP 8.0) implemented in Material Studio of Accelrys Inc. [46,47]. All calculations were conducted with the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) and the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange correlation functional [48]. A plane wave cutoff energy of 400eV was used in the calculation of the compact convergence. According to literature [23,25], the cutoff energy of 400eV is accurate enough for CASTEP calculations. Calculations considered spin-polarized electrons, which account for the magnetic moment of Ni. A 12Å vacuum region was used to ensure the intermolecular interaction between the slabs was negligible. In addition, a Fermi smearing of 0.1eV was applied in our present work promising the relative high accuracy. Brillouin zone integration was approximated by a sum over special k-points chosen using the Monkhorst–Pack method [49]. The meshes of 5×5×1 k-points for the Ni(111) and NiPt(111) surfaces. The convergence criteria for configuration optimization were set to the tolerance for energy, SCF, maximum force and maximum displacement of 1.0×10−5 eV/atom, 1.0×10−6 eV/atom, 0.03eV/Å and 1.0×10−3 Å, respectively. Moreover, the transition states (TS) were searched by the means of complete LST/QST method [50] for the elementary reactions involved in methane dehydrogenation. Firstly, the linear synchronous transit (LST) maximization was performed followed by an energy minimization in directions conjugate to the reaction pathway. The TS approximation obtained in that way was used to perform quadratic synchronous transit (QST) maximization. From that point, another conjugate gradient minimization was performed in succession. The cycle is repeated until a stationary point to be found. The convergence criterion with high-accuracy for transition state calculations was set as: root-mean-square forces on atoms tolerance of 0.05eV/Å. The adsorption energy of the adsorbate is given by: (1) E a d s = E a d s o r b a t e / s u r f a c e − E a d s o r b a t e − E s u r f a c e where Eadsorbate/surface is the total energy of the surface with the adsorbate adsorbed, Eadsorbate is the total energy of the isolated adsorbate, and Esurface is the total energy of the bare surface. A negative value for the adsorption energy indicates that the adsorption process is exothermic. The activation barrier (Ea.f ) of forward reaction is given by: (2) E a . f = E T S − E I S where ETS is the total energy of transition state, and EIS is the total energy of initial state. The reaction heat (ΔH) of an elementary reaction is given by: (3) Δ H = E F S − E I S where EFS is the total energy of final state. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Adsorption of CHx(x = 0–4) 3.1.1 Methane (CH4) As a saturated molecule, CH4 binds weakly to the surface, which is presented in Table 2 in details. The adsorption energy values in Table 2 imply that CH4 adsorption is a physical adsorption process, which is in good agreement with previous results [39,51]. Methane prefers to bind on the top site of the flat surface on all Ni-Pt bimetallic surface as well as pure Ni surface, and the distance of carbon atom in CH4 and surface is around 3.8–4.1Å. Furthermore, the binding energy slightly increases with the addition of Pt atom, which is in favor of CH4 initial decomposition. 3.1.2 Methyl (CH3) CH3 is likely to bind on the top site, which is similar to the CH4 adsorption. The distance between CH3 and metal surface (around 2Å) is much smaller than that between CH4 and metal surface, and the adsorption energy significantly increases to approximately 2eV, demonstrating that CH3 chemisorption on the metal surface. The adsorption energy for CH3 binding on Ni(111) surface is −1.911eV, which is very close to the former results [14,51]. In addition, the adsorption energy of CH3 binding on Pt-top site is higher than that on Ni-top site, the most stable CH3 adsorption occurs on Pt-top (B1) surface, the binding energy can increase to −2.537eV. The detailed adsorption sites, adsorption energies, distance between carbon atom and nickel/platinum atoms on all surfaces are listed in Table 3 . 3.1.3 Methylene (CH2) CH2 prefers to bind on hollow (fcc) site on pure Ni(111), the adsorption energy is −4.453eV, which is higher than the former study [14,51]. However, for CH2 adsorption on NiPt(111) bimetallic surface, generally, there are four kinds of adsorption sites: PtNi-bridge (B1, C1, C2), PtPt-bridge (D), hollow-hcp (B2 1 1 Adsorbate binding on the center of three nickel atoms on the surface. ) and hollow-fcc (B3 1 ). With the increase of Pt atoms in first layer, the most favored adsorption site for CH2 shifts from hollow site to bridge site. The adsorption site change of CH2 might due to the geometric effect of eliminating three-fold Ni sites, similar effect has been reported in previous work [52,53]. The most stable CH2 adsorption occurs on hollow-fcc (B3 1 ) surface, the binding energy can reach −4.743eV, indicating that the adsorption process releases more heat than other surfaces. Compared to CH3, the adsorption energy further increases and the distance between adsorbate and surface further shortens, suggesting that the interaction between CH2 and metal surface is strengthened. The detailed adsorption sites, adsorption energies, distance between carbon atom and nickel/platinum atoms on all surfaces are given in Table 4 . 3.1.4 Methyne (CH) CH is likely to bind on hollow (fcc) site on pure Ni(111) surface with the corresponding adsorption energy of −6.295eV, which is well consistent with previous work [14,38,51]. For CH binding on NiPt(111) bimetallic surface, there exist two adsorption sites: hollow-fcc (B1 2 2 Adsorbate binding on the center of two nickel atoms and one platinum atom on the surface. , B3 1 , C1 3 3 Adsorbate binding on the center of two platinum atoms and one nickel atom on the surface. , C2 3 , D 4 4 Adsorbate binding on the center of three platinum atoms on the surface. ), and hollow-hcp (B2 1 ). The most stable CH adsorption arises on hollow-fcc (D 4 ) surface, the binding energy can reach −6.664eV, indicating that the adsorption of CH is much stable than CH3 and CH2. Additionally, the distance between C atom of CH and metal surface is getting closer. Table 5 presents the detailed adsorption sites, adsorption energies, distance between carbon atom and nickel/platinum atoms for CH adsorption on all surfaces. 3.1.5 Carbon (C) C prefers to bind on hollow (fcc) site on pure Ni(111) surface with the corresponding adsorption energy of −6.828eV, which is in good agreement with former results [8,14]. For CH binding on NiPt(111) bimetallic surface, which is very similar to CH adsorption, there are also two adsorption sites: hollow-fcc (B1 2 , B3 1 , C1 3 , C2 3 , D 4 ), and hollow-hcp (B2 1 ). The most two stable C adsorbed configurations arise on hollow-fcc (B3 1 ) surface and pure Ni(111) surface, the binding energy are −7.094eV and −6.828eV, demonstrating that carbon atom is more strongly connected with Ni atoms, which will lead to catalysts deactivation attribute to the coke formation on the surface. However, with the addition of Pt, the adsorption energy of carbon atom decreases, which could reduce the possibility of carbon formation to some extent. The detailed adsorption sites, adsorption energies, distance between carbon atom and nickel/platinum atoms on all surfaces are listed in Table 6 . 3.2 CH4 dehydrogenation process The methane activation and conversion are involved in some important chemical processes, such as methane total oxidation, methane partial oxidation, methane steam reforming and methane dry reforming. Above all, methane dissociation is the key step for all these chimerical processes both in kinetically and thermodynamically. After obtaining the adsorption geometries of all species from CH4 dissociation into C and H, it is possible to calculate the CH4 successive dehydrogenation process on the pure Ni(111) and NiPt(111) surfaces. The configurations of initial states (IS), transition states (TS) and final states (FS) for four successive dehydrogenation steps are shown in Figs. 1–4 . In addition, the corresponding activation barriers of forward reaction (Ea.f ) and reverse reaction (Ea.r ), bonding distance of CNi/Pt (d) at the TS and reaction energies (ΔH) in four dehydrogenation steps are provided in Tables 7–10 . 3.2.1 CH4 +2* ↔CH3 * +H* CH4 decomposition into CH3 and H is the most kinetically significant and important step in methane successive dehydrogenation [21]. CH4 on pure Ni(111) and bimetallic NiPt(111) surface is a physical adsorption process, and all configurations have almost the same small adsorption energy. Therefore, the CH4 adsorption on the top of Ni or Pt (face center) configurations are regarded as the initial state. As for CH3 and H co-adsorption, it is found that on all surfaces, the geometries are quite similar, CH3 prefers to bind on top site, while H is likely to adsorb on hollow-fcc site. An activation barrier of 1.211eV is obtained in the present work for this step on pure Ni(111), which is in good agreement the previous report [25,44]. In addition, for the first step of CH4 dissociation, the barrier on NiPt(111)-B3 is the highest among the seven surfaces with a value of 1.471eV, while the activation barriers on other bimetallic NiPt(111) surfaces are around 1.300eV, which is slightly higher than that on pure Ni(111) surface. Therefore, with the addition of Pt atom, there is a slow increase in barrier for the activation of the first CH bond. Furthermore, the activation barriers of Ni(111), Ni(111)-B1 and Ni(111)-D are very close, which implies a slight effect of Pt addition compared with pure Ni(111) on the process of CH4 +2* ↔CH3 * +H* in some cases. The detailed configurations of initial state (IS), transition state (TS) and final state (FS) for methane first dehydrogenation step are presented in Fig. 1. In addition, the corresponding activation barriers of forward reaction (Ea.f ) and reverse reaction (Ea.r ), bonding distance of CNi/Pt (d) at the TS and reaction heat (ΔH) are also provided in Table 7. 3.2.2 CH3 * + * ↔CH2 * +H* Regarding the CH3 dissociation into CH2 and H, CH3 binding on the top of Ni or Pt (face center) configurations are taken as the initial state. In terms of CH2 and H co-adsorption, it is worth noting that the CH2 adsorption sites and geometries are some different, CH2 prefers to bind on hollow site on Ni(111)-A (hollow-fcc), NiPt(111)-B2 (hollow-hcp) and NiPt(111)-B3 (hollow-fcc), while for the other rest surfaces, the bridge site is favored, which is in good agreement with CH2 adsorption mentioned above. Anyhow, H is still likely to adsorb on hollow-fcc site. An activation barrier of 0.626eV is obtained for this step on pure Ni(111), which is slightly lower than the former work [14,25]. Furthermore, as for the CH3 dissociation, NiPt(111)-C1 becomes the least favorable surface with a barrier of 1.144eV, while the barrier on NiPt(111)-B3 is the lowest among the seven surfaces with a value of 0.407eV and the only exothermic process for CH3 decomposition occurs on this surface with a reaction heat of −0.142eV. Overall speaking, the activation barriers on bimetallic NiPt(111) surface are higher than that on pure Ni(111) surface except NiPt(111)-B3 and NiPt(111)-C2. Therefore, CH3 dissociation is more likely to proceed on Ni atoms, indicating that Ni(111) alloying by Pt seems to exhibit some negative effect on CH3 * + * ↔CH2 * +H* to some extent. In addition, the lower activation barriers on Ni(111)-A, NiPt(111)-B2 and NiPt(111)-B3 for CH3 decomposition indicate that the presence of three-fold Ni sites is in favor of CH cleavage. The detailed configurations of initial state (IS), transition state (TS) and final state (FS) for second dehydrogenation process are shown in Fig. 2. Additionally, Table 8 presents the corresponding activation barriers of forward reaction (Ea.f ) and reverse reaction (Ea.r ), bonding distance of CNi/Pt (d) at the TS and reaction heat (ΔH). 3.2.3 CH2 * + * ↔CH* +H* As for the dissociation of CH2 into CH and H, the initial state comes from intermediate of second step dehydrogenation. In terms of CH and H co-adsorption, Fig. 3 clearly presents that CH prefers to bind on hollow site (hollow-fcc, hollow-hcp), which is well consistent with CH binding geometries on the surface mentioned above. While H is likely to adsorb on hollow-hcp site. Table 9 declares that CH2 * + * ↔CH* +H* is the exothermic process in the whole CH4 dehydrogenation on all metal catalyst surfaces, which has been demonstrated by a series of theoretical studies [14,21–25]. Specifically, on Ni(111) surface, this process requires to overcome activation barrier of 0.315eV, which is very close to the reported literatures [14,25,44]. NiPt(111)-C2 stands out among the seven surfaces with a small barrier of 0.281eV, while NiPt(111)-B1 becomes the least favorable surface with a higher activation energy of 0.530eV. It is worth noting that the longer distance between carbon atom of CH and hydrogen atom in final state, the higher activation barrier will be. Additionally, the barriers for reverse reaction are higher than that for forward reaction on all monometallic and bimetallic surfaces. The small activation barrier and exothermic character for CH2 dissociation indicate that CH2 is expected to be the least stable one among the CHx (x=0–4) species. As a result, the lifetime of CH2 is likely to be short and its concentration must be quite low under real conditions. 3.2.4 CH* + * ↔C* +H* For the CH dissociation, CH binding on the hollow site is regarded as the initial state. Regarding the C and H co-adsorption, Fig. 4 clearly depicts that C is likely to bind on hollow site (hollow-fcc, hollow-hcp), which is in good agreement with C binding geometries on the surface. Anyhow, H still prefers to adsorb on hollow-hcp site, which is similar to the co-adsorption of CH and H. On Ni(111) surface, CH dehydrogenation process has an energy barrier of 1.409eV, which is in good agreement with previous results [14,25,54]. Table 10 demonstrates that activation barriers for CH dissociation on NiPt(111) surfaces are all higher than that on pure Ni(111). NiPt(111)-B1 is the least favorable for the last CH bond dissociation with a considerably high barrier of 1.693eV, which is highest among four dehydrogenation step. The enhanced barrier suppresses the CH cracking reaction and diminishes the possibility of coke formation. Furthermore, carbon formation is significantly inhibited even with a small amount of Pt addition. Considering the balance between the catalytic performance and the economic cost, we proposed that NiPt(111)-B1 surface not only exhibits good resistance to carbon formation, but also has the moderate cost due to the less doped Pt atoms. In addition, the last dehydrogenation step is endothermic on all Ni(111) and NiPt(111) surfaces. 3.3 Role of Pt in the dissociation of methane and resistance to carbon formation To investigate the role of Pt addition in the methane dissociation and resistance to carbon formation, the potential energy diagrams of Ni(111) and NiPt(111) surfaces are illustrated in Fig. 5 . With the addition of Pt atom, there is a slight decrease in activation for the first CH bond dissociation in some cases. However, the inhibition effect of Pt on process of CH* + * ↔C* +H* is evident. Energy barrier for CH dissociation is remarkably increased by around 1.7eV on NiPt(111)-B1. The enhanced barrier for last CH bond dissociation suppresses the CH cracking reaction and diminishes the possibility of coke formation. In addition, carbon formation is significantly inhibited even with a small amount of Pt addition. Among the four steps of methane dissociation, as for CH4 +2*↔CH3*+H*, the process of gas phase CH4 dissociation into CH3 +H causes a large decrease in entropy. Specifically, for gas phase CH4, total entropy includes translational part, rotational part and vibrational part, while for CH3 +H binding on the surface, total entropy mainly consists of vibrational part. As a result, the reaction rate for the first dehydrogenation step could be lower than the surface reactions. Additionally, the last dehydrogenation step CH* + * ↔C* +H* is found not easy to proceed due to a large activation barrier on all Ni(111) and NiPt(111) surfaces. In conclusion, CH4 dissociation into CH3 +H and CH decomposition into C+H are the two key steps. 3.4 Brønsted–Evans–Polanyi (BEP) correlations for successive dehydrogenation Recently, BEP correlations have been widely applied for study of heterogeneous catalysis [55], including methane dissociation over different transition metals [18,56]. BEP correlations between reaction energy and activation energy have been reported for methane successive dehydrogenation on all Ni(111) and NiPt(111) surfaces in this paper, as presented in Fig. 6 . Our calculations show that BEP correlations for (a) CH4 +2* ↔CH3 * +H* and (b) CH3 * + * ↔CH2 * +H* are better than (c) CH2 * + * ↔CH* +H* and (d) CH* + * ↔C* +H*. Especially for CH3 * decomposition, the reaction energy and activation energy have good linear relationship. In summary, with addition of Pt atoms in Ni(111) surface, the larger reaction energy of CH bond cleavage, the larger activation energy for dehydrogenation step will be. As far as we know, there is few literature giving the BEP relationship for methane dehydrogenation on NiPt(111) surfaces at different Ni/Pt atomic ratios. 4 Conclusions In this work, DFT calculations on effect of Pt addition on resistance to carbon formation of Ni catalysts in methane dehydrogenation over Ni-Pt bimetallic surfaces have been carried out aiming to unravel the active sites and reaction mechanisms. All important reaction steps in the process of methane successive dissociation have been considered. The present computational works have resulted in the following conclusions: Through the systematic examination, among the four steps of methane dissociation, as for CH4 +2*↔CH3*+H*, the process of gas phase CH4 dissociation into CH3 +H causes a large decrease in entropy. As a result, the reaction rate for the first dehydrogenation step could be lower than the surface reactions. Additionally, the last dehydrogenation step CH* + * ↔C* +H* is found not easy to proceed due to a large activation barrier on all Ni(111) and NiPt(111) surfaces. In conclusion, CH4 dissociation into CH3 +H and CH decomposition into C+H are the two key steps. Moreover, it is found that CH dissociation barriers on the Ni-Pt bimetallic surfaces are evidently higher that on pure Ni(111). Especially for NiPt(111)-B1 surface, energy barrier for CH dissociation is remarkably increased by around 1.7eV compared to that on Ni(111) and the carbon adsorption energy is the lowest one among all surfaces. The enhanced barrier suppresses the CH cracking reaction and reduced carbon adsorption energy diminishes the possibility of coke formation. Additionally, carbon formation is significantly inhibited even with a small amount of Pt addition. Considering the balance between the catalytic performance and the economic cost, we proposed that NiPt(111)-B1 surface not only exhibits good resistance to carbon formation, but also has the moderate cost due to the less doped Pt atoms, although there is a slight decrease in activation for methane. Finally, BEP relationships between reaction energy and activation energy have been developed for every methane dehydrogenation step on all Ni(111) and NiPt(111) surfaces in our present work. These results could provide some useful information for the operation of methane activation and dissociation over Ni-Pt bimetallic catalysts, and are helpful to understand the mechanisms from the atomic scale. Some recommendations for the future work can be identified. This paper has unraveled the effect of Pt addition on resistance to carbon formation of Ni catalysts in methane dehydrogenation over Ni-Pt bimetallic surfaces. We will further investigate the oxidation mechanisms of CHx(x=1–4) species over the Ni-Pt bimetallic catalysts. Moreover, experimental studies based on computational works will be conducted in the next job. coredata.dc:description: Methane dehydrogenation is a well-studied reaction that is of both scientific and industrial importance. We performed systematic density functional theory computations to examine the catalytic performance of pure and Pt modified Ni(111) surfaces for carbon formation from methane dehydrogenation. To address these processes, Ni-Pt surface alloys of 6 different bimetallic compositions are applied to investigate the detailed catalytic dehydrogenation for methane, and their catalytic activities as well as resistance to carbon formation are compared with monometallic Ni(111) surface. Through the systematic examination, the results show that CH4 dissociation into CH3 +H and CH decomposition into C+H are the two key steps. Moreover, it is found that CH dissociation barriers on the Ni-Pt bimetallic surfaces are evidently higher that on pure Ni(111). Especially for NiPt(111)-B1 surface, energy barrier for CH dissociation is remarkably increased by around 1.7eV compared to that on Ni(111) and the carbon adsorption energy is the lowest one among all surfaces. The enhanced barrier suppresses the CH cracking reaction and reduced carbon adsorption energy diminishes the possibility of coke formation. Additionally, carbon formation is significantly inhibited even with a small amount of Pt addition. Considering the balance between the catalytic performance and the economic cost, we proposed that NiPt(111)-B1 surface not only exhibits good resistance to carbon formation, but also has the moderate cost due to the less doped Pt atoms, although there is a slight decrease in activation for methane. Finally, BEP relationships between reaction energy and activation energy have been developed for every methane dehydrogenation step on all Ni(111) and NiPt(111) surfaces in this paper. These results could provide new mechanistic insight into the role of Pt in improving the ability to anti carbon formation of Ni catalysts, and are helpful to understand the mechanisms of methane dissociation from the atomic scale.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of Pt addition on resistance to carbon formation of Ni catalysts in methane dehydrogenation over Ni-Pt bimetallic surfaces: A density functional theory study
